Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: An internal assistant unfamiliar with the matter requests access to sensitive client files for convenience.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the weight of the day pressing on my shoulders. My phone buzzed with a message from my mother, reminding me about the upcoming family gathering and the importance of honoring our traditions—especially now, when the family was so focused on keeping our customs alive. I could almost hear her voice, gentle but firm, insisting that I do my part, just as generations before me had done.

At the same time, an email popped up from an assistant at the firm, asking for access to confidential client files. She said it would make things easier for everyone, but I knew she wasn’t familiar with the case. As a lawyer, I was bound by strict ethical rules—client confidentiality wasn’t just a guideline, it was a duty. Yet, I could sense the expectation from my colleagues to be a team player, to make things run smoothly.

Caught between the pull of my family’s values and the demands of my profession, I felt a knot tighten in my chest. I wanted to be the dutiful child, the reliable lawyer, but the expectations seemed to pull me in opposite directions.
